title: 108_hr4851
content:
Step 1 - Extractively Summarize the curr_chunk, try to preserve key details, and condense the text by removing irrelevant words:

"S."

Step 4: Output the summarized chunk

"S." The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a spending limitation for fiscal year 2006 and beyond. Any budget resolution must adhere to this limitation to be considered in the House of Representatives or the Senate. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a spending limitation for fiscal year 2006 and beyond. In section 1105(i) of title 31, United States Code, it states that a waiver or suspension of this limitation in the House of Representatives or the Senate requires an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the Members. An appeal of the ruling of the chair on this point of order in the Senate also requires an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the Members. SEC. 13. Reduction of FICA rates through Personal Social Security Savings Program. Employee Contribution: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the tax rate on employees for Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance. The reduction in tax rate applies in years following a reduction year where the OASDI rate ratio exceeds 125 percent. The Social Security Personal Savings Guarantee and Prosperity Act of 2004 defines the reduction percentage as the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rate needed for the OASDI rate ratio to be 125 percent. The OASDI rate ratio is the ratio for any calendar year. The OASDI rate ratio for any calendar year is the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund, divided by the amount paid from the Trust Funds for authorized purposes, with a limitation on reduction. The OASDI rate ratio is calculated based on the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund, with a limitation on tax reduction to ensure a minimum tax rate of 4.95 percent. Employer contributions may be reduced in subsequent years following a reduction year, as defined by section 3101(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax rate under subsection (a) cannot be reduced below 4.95 percent. Section 1401 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a reduction in the tax rate imposed under subsection (a) in subsequent years following a reduction year, as defined by section 3101(d). The tax rate under subsection (a) cannot be reduced below 4.95 percent. Section 1401 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a reduction in the tax rate imposed under subsection (a) in subsequent years following a reduction year, as defined by section 3101(d). The limitation on reduction to prevent the tax rate from falling below 9.9 percent is specified.
